content: Justice Department not taking stand on appeal of gay officer's firing Calling it a "procedural decision," the U.S. Justice Department is staying out of a federal lawsuit challenging the dismissal of an Air Force officer under the military gay ban being reviewed by a federal court. Former Air Force Maj. Margaret Witt's case was dismissed by a federal judge, but is now being reconsidered by order of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The Washington Blade
reply: Justice Department not taking stand on appeal of gay officer's firing Calling it a "procedural decision," the U.S. Justice Department is staying out of a federal lawsuit challenging the dismissal of an Air Force officer under the military gay ban being reviewed by a federal court. title: Justice Department not taking stand on appeal of gay officer's firing

content: Wonder if they're gambling on the court giving them a reason to change policy so they don;t have to expend as much political capital. I don't really like the approach if so, but it is intriguing.

content: If I am not mistaken, the object is to make the AF prove in court that she (the officer) was a 'threat to unit cohesion' since that is why she got canned. In this case, btw, it was her jilted lover that turned her in. (She is from the AF base I teach at.) This message has been edited. Last edited by: reducetension, Tue 05 May 2009 08:16 PM

content: The problem with it is the fact that the court traditionally just takes the word of the military in these cases, evidence not being necessary. The venue is a nice move, though.
